bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, August 29, 1941

div1.p: Hench reports that Camp Lazear and the remains of Building No. 1 have been located. He has bought the building and hopes to raise money for a memorial. The Cuban government accepted his report. Hench has found Lazear's death certificate.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, August 29, 1941
div1.p:
I was sure I had written you something about my Cuban trip, and am
much ashamed to find that I did not. Let me tell you briefly that without
a shadow of doubt we located Camp Lazear and the remains of Building #1,
rickety but still standing. I bought the building and hope to raise money
to buy the rest of Camp Lazear site and properly memorialize it. I have
had a few repairs made (very carefully) to the building. I enclose some
photographs which I took inside and outside the building. The governmental
authorities in Cuba completely accepted my report; Ramos wrote me a typical
sugary Cuban letter. Doctor Recio, secretary of sanitation, viewed the spot
and building, and enthusiastically endorsed our verification. I will write
later more of my plan to raise money.

Meanwhile, let me send you (what I was sure I had sent) a copy of
my Cleveland talk and a copy of a photo taken at the unveiling. Please
return the photo, but keep the talk. However, it will be published with
colored illustrations in Hygeia in October, and I will send you as many
reprints as you wish. By the way, two days after the Cleveland affair
Kissinger had a stroke and nearly died. He has made a pretty good recovery
and is now walking about the house some.

Thanks loads for helping on the matter of a name for the anonymous
figures in the painting. They may not accept our suggestions, but we gave
'em! I just heard again from General Kean, who favors inserting Pinto
rather than Ames, but he told Kellogg that he would abide by your sugges-
tion favoring Ames.

As always, gratefully yours,
P. S. Hench, M. D.
psh:pw
Enc.
P. S. How is your manuscript coming? Can I help in any way? Do
you have a publisher?

As you may have noticed I found Dr. Lazear's death certificate made
out by you. This I found in the National Archives. You may not have a
copy and I had one made for you. When I was in Havana I saw an advertisement
in the Havana papers of the Trotcha Hotel. I recalled the happy times you
had had (at the Trocha Hotel in 1900, noted in your manuscript). I asked
Moran if it could be the same despite the slightly different spelling.
In our wanderings we drove around there and talked to the present pro-
prietor. He said it was the same old hotel so for auld lang syne I took
a snapshot of it for you. Do you recognize it? It is now almost completely
filled with European exiles, domiciled in Cuba or waiting to come to the
U. S. (It is at 7th and 2nd St., Vedado, I think).

With the help of an architect-friend here I am trying to transpose
the old buildings of Columbia Barracks onto the current (1940) map of the
Military Hospital, Ciudad Militar so that all those interested in medical
history will know exactly where Reed's laboratory, the officers' quarters,
etc. were in relation to the buildings now there. When I get this done, I
will send you the result.

I was delighted with the frank and helpful comments you and Gen.
Kean wrote on my Hemmeter photostats. When I see you this next spring I'll
tell you of the very strange reception I got from Carroll's son. Have you
ever read Dominguez' book on Finlay? It is in French but I have an English
translation and if you'd care to read it I'll lend it to you gladly.

P. S. Hench, M. D.
Addendum II (Aug 29)
answered his letter of Aug 26
